titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V.45. Mr: Nathl. H. Strong this morning brought me dispatches from the Secretary of State; one addressed to Mr Bayard and myself—the other to me alone— Letters from Mr Gallatin and Mr Bayard, at Amsterdam, and one from Mr Bourne, enclosing one from Mr Beasley.— The despatch to Mr Bayard and me, of which Mr Bayard retained the original, and enclosed to me a Copy, directs us both, to repair immediately upon the receipt of it to Gothenburg, there to enter upon a Negotiation for Peace with England, conformably to a proposal made by the British Government, and accepted by that of the United-States. Mr Monroe intimates that there will be other American Commissioners, but his letter is dated 8. Jany: before the Nominations were made— Mr Henry Clay and Mr Jonathan Russell were the persons ultimately appointed. Mr Gallatin
is not in the Commission. Mr Monroe directs me to leave the Affairs of the United States here, in my absence, in the charge of Mr Harris. Mr Strong left England the 25th: of February, and Amsterdam the 9th: of March— He passed Mr Harris on the road. He had a number of private letters for me—a Packet from Mr Beasley, and Packets of Newspapers and Public Documents, all of which he left on Board the English Packet in which he came to Holland— He was obliged to land upon the island of Goree, and to leave his trunk on board the Packet. He sent me a few National Intelligencers of October, November and December. They occupied me the whole day and Evening, excepting the time of a ride with Mrs: Adams after dinner, when I called at the door of Princess Michel Galitzin, and left a letter which Mr Gallatin had enclosed to me for her. Mr Beasley’s letter is of 1. March and expresses doubts whether the British Government would appoint Commissioners to meet us at Gothenburg. A rumour of the same kind has been prevailing here for some time among the English Merchants, and places me under some embarrassment what determination to take. Mr Lewis spent part of the Evening here— This day the news came of the last ineffectual struggles of Napoleon to save Paris.

2. VI:15. I sent this morning to the British Minister, Lord Walpole, requesting to see him, and to know the time when I should find him at home. He appointed One O’Clock this afternoon— Mr: Norman called upon me and I had some conversation with him, concerning the most advisable manner of proceeding to Gothenburg; which at this Season of the year is not without difficulty— The Gulph of Bothnia, being just at this Season passable neither upon the ice, nor in Boats. Mr Norman has travelled between this place and Gothenburg several times, and now intends to go there as soon as the Mails expected from England shall have arrived— He thinks the shortest and safest way of going at this Season, will be by the way of Memel, and there embarking to proceed by water. He intends going thus himself, and if I should finally conclude to go, leaving my family here, I agreed with him that we should go together— He told me that he believed Schmidt, who was Mr Harris’s Clerk would be glad to go with me, as my private Secretary— He writes a fine hand, and Harris considered him as so confidential that he employed him to copy all the Papers under the former Mission Extraordinary— I shall want some such assistance, but this Young Man is not to me quite so confidential as he might be to Harris— Norman told me also that he dined yesterday at Lewis’s in company with this Mr Strong, who said that he was desirous also of being private Secretary to either of the American Ministers— I called upon Lord Walpole at one O’Clock—the hour he had appointed— Told him the order I had received to go to Gothenburg, and asked him if he could inform me whether Commissioners on the part of Great-Britain had been appointed— He said he could not; that he had received no dispatches from his Government of later date than 24. December. There are now 22 Mails from England due.— But he said by his last accounts from Stockholm of the 23d. of March he learnt that some of the Mails were landed—they might be expected every day— He had heard from private letters that George Hammond had been appointed; but there must be others— He did not know who— Perhaps Mr Foster might be one— But he could hardly conjecture who it would be— George Hammond was getting to be an old Man; he must be near sixty, and he was very fat— I told him I had known Mr Hammond from the year 1783 when he was Secretary to Mr Hartley the British Commissioner at the definitive Treaty of Peace— That he was then a Student at Oxford, where I afterwards saw him. That he must be now about 51 years old.— I mentioned the Letter from Lord Castlereagh to Mr Monroe proposing the direct Negotiation, and told him I was surprized to find in it stated, that Lord Catchcart’s Note to Count Nesselrode had been made known to the American Plenipotentiaries, and they had answered that overture contained in it.— That in fact no Communication of it ever had been made to us— That excepting what he, Lord Walpole had told me of it I never knew any thing of this Note, untill I found it Yesterday in the printed Documents I had received.— He said he had no doubt that the knowledge of it had been purposely withheld from us, because if it had been communicated, Russia would have had nothing further to do with the matter, but Romanzoff had got into his head some wild and absurd project of a Congress and a Maritime Law; and he, Walpole, was as sure as he was of his own existence, and he believed he could prove it that Romanzoff had been cheating us all.— In the first place the Mediation had never been proposed to Great Britain untill they were informed of the Appointment of the American Ministers— When they received this information Lord Cathcart was ordered verbally to decline the acceptance of it; which he did at Bautzen in June— The Emperor said in answer to this, that he could have nothing further to do in the business—that he had written so to Romanzoff, and had ordered him to make the Communication to the American Ministers— His answer to Lord Cathcart had been; well, I can do no more in the business—“Je m’en lave les Mains.”— That Romanzoff on receiving this order, instead of obeying it, had sent it back to the Emperor, with a project of his own, to renew the offer of the Mediation, which the Emperor did afterwards approve, and the Instruction to renew the offer of Mediation was sent to Count Lieven, which he did.— That Romanzoff knew perfectly well the
answer of the British Government, and he, Walpole believed that he could produce proof of it, which would be receivable in a Court of Justice; though he would not say so positively— That Romanzoff had told him so himself; that he knew it unofficially; and not otherwise— He pretended that the only knowledge he had if it was by a letter which General Moreau had written to Monsieur Gallatin, and which Monsieur Gallatin had shewn to him, stating that Lord Cathcart had told Moreau the English Government had rejected the Mediation. But Romanzoff must forsooth cling to his project of a Maritime law— It was the folly of all the Russians— Ever since the year 1780 he did not believe there was a Russian breathing, but was infected with this absurdity of Maritime Law— A Maritime Law by compact between one power and another was a very proper thing, and assuredly if there was a liberal maritime Law in the world it was that of the Treaty between England, and Russia, and what could they want more? Yet even such men as Prince Czartorinski and Novosiltzoff, (Czartorinski was undoubtedly a very superior Man— Novoziltzoff was not— He was a very fair, honourable man, but he meant superior, in intellect) even they some years ago, after a dispatch which had no concern or relation with the subject—“à propos de botte”—had added a Postscript, saying that they hoped England would hereafter relax in her Principles of Maritime Law— Maritime Law!— Russia! said Mylord, and reddened as he spoke; why Russia may fight us till she sinks, and she will get no Maritime Law from us— That is, no change in the Maritime Law— Maritime Law submitted to a Congress! what can there be upon Earth, more absurd?— I said that whatever Count Romanzoff’s projects about maritime Law might have been, he had never manifested to me the most distant idea of connecting them with this Mediation— That the offer of Mediation came form the Emperor himself— That Count Romanzoff told me it was made to England at the same time as to the United States— That it was merely as a common friend anxious for the restoration of Peace between the two parties, that the Emperor had made the offer— Not a syllable upon the subject of maritime Law had ever been said to me by the Count throughout the whole transaction— However, I added, that much as I regretted the failure of this attempt to accomplish a Peace, I hoped the issue of the new effort, by direct Negotiation, would be more propitious— Lord Walpole said he understood the expectations from it were very sangwine, both in England and in America; I said I had heard they were in America; and it was natural they should be for an object that was so much desired— He said that wherever the Misunderstanding in the former case originated it was to be regretted, for he was perswaded that had it not happened, the Peace might have been made eight months ago.— He said he heard Mr Russell was in the New Commission; and he looked sour in pronouncing his name—and Mr Clay—whom he did not know.— I told him that I had no official information of the names— Mr Bayard and my self were ordered to Gothenburg, with intimations that other Commissioners would be joined with us, and meet us there.— I had heard that Mr Russell was appointed Minister to Sweden, and he might be joined in the Commission on that account.— Mr Clay, at the time of his appointment was Speaker of the House of Representatives of the United States. I concluded by asking him if he should receive any account of the appointment of British Commissioners, to have the goodness to inform me of it, as it would hasten my departure if I saw a probability that they might soon be there— I should be sorry to make any person wait there an hour for me— He said if he heard of an appointment he would give me immediate notice— That he expected some of the Mails every hour, and they could not be much longer delayed. He had told me that he himself had written Lord Cathcart’s note to Nesselrode of 1. September— That he thinks it was written at Prague, the 23d: or 24th: of August, but not presented untill they came to Töplitz— Our Conversation was of about half an hour— Mr Strong, Mr Lewis and Mr Slade dined with us— I had asked Mr Montreal, who called on me this morning, but he was unwell, and asked me to excuse him. Baron Blome had also paid me a visit while I was abroad this Morning.

3. VI:30. Read prayers for the Sunday before Easter, and Massillon’s Sermon upon the Benediction of the Standards of the Regiment of Catinat, which closes the Volume of the Petit-Carême. Gave Charles his lessons, and the rest of the day was occupied in writing the Journal of Yesterday. Mr Lewis sent me a letter which he has received from Mr Redwood; dated Amsterdam 7. March. It was to have come by Mr Strong, but missed him and came by the Post. A mixture of political and commercial news. It says that Mr: Bayard wanted the Neptune to go to Gothenburg, and Mr Gallatin to go to America.

4. VI. Took a long walk this morning before Breakfast, with Charles. Wrote to Mr Harris, informing him that I am instructed to leave the affairs of the United States here in his charge, in my absence; and suggesting the expediency of his return. Enclosed the letter, to Mr Bourne, at Amsterdam— Mr Dobell called upon me to take leave. He is to go the day after to-morrow, for Weimar; Carlsruhe, and the Emperor Alexander’s Head-Quarters— Mr Hurd likewise paid me a morning visit. I wrote a Note to Mr Weydemeyer, requesting a conference
with him. In my walk after dinner I met Mr de Tracy, who still flatters himself with hopes against hope— The allies did meet an unexpected, momentary check, which has delayed about a Month their entrance into Paris, and may possibly delay it some weeks longer— But they are again upon the offensive on all sides, and on every quarter gaining great advantages. Tracy’s only resource of incredulity is that no official Accounts of these Events are published here, coming directly from the Emperor’s Head-Quarter’s. But all the essential accounts, however inofficial, eventually prove to be true.— Charles is at home from School for the Easter Holidays; ten days, which will run out to a fortnight; but I am now so much engaged that I am compelled to renounce giving him his lessons myself— Mrs Adams now takes that charge.

5. VI. Received a note from Mr: Weydemeyer saying that he is sick and unable now to see me. I called and settled my Account at the English Magazine— Mr Weeks spoke to me again about the fine he was obliged to pay at the Police, on Account of one of my Servants, while I lived in his house— But he has changed his tone— He began by making the demand boldly, and with threats. He now appeals to my compassion and generosity— But as the neglect of his own Housekeeper to ask for the Paper, the want of which occasioned the fine, was the occasion of its being levied, I think he has no more claim upon my generosity than upon my Justice.— In my after dinner’s walk I called upon Mr Lewis with whom I found Mr Slade and Mr Dobell— I sat with him untill near ten O’Clock.— He has no good opinion of Strong; and told me circumstances respecting him and his projects, not at-all to his credit— I asked Mr Dobell to write me from Memel, if he finds the Navigation there open, or likely to be so. He promised me he would. Pierre Ouvré my Steward asked me this day for his dismissal— He is obliged to go to Moscow to see his brother who is sick. He has lived with me ever since I have been in this Country, and is one of the best Servants I ever had.

6. VI:15. I was engaged great part of this day in going round the City to look at travelling Carriages for sale. I found however none to suit me. After dinner I took a ride with Mrs: Adams— Mr Smith dined with Mr Lewis. Received this Evening a letter from Mr Hurd, asking further advice respecting the sale of Mr Gray’s Indigo. This was a Great Holiday— The Annunciation of the Virgin Mary.

7. VI. Mr Strong called upon me this morning, and told me that he believed he should proceed to Gothenburg by the way of Finland, and Stockholm; and his intention was to go as soon as possible— He believed in about a fortnight. Dr: Galloway also paid me a visit.— He always talks politics, and thinks because the Berlin Post and the Courier’s have been detained a day or two by the badness of the roads, and perhaps the breaking up of the rivers, that the Allies have been defeated again, and made a second retreat. This sort of mistrust, and distrust here is very common; but in the present case is totally without rational foundation. Nothing is more improbable— I was employed untill dinner in writing an official Note to Mr Weydemeyer, which I intended to have postponed untill after having a Conversation with him— But having waited two days and being pressed for time I thought it best to delay no longer. when my note was just ready I received a notification from Mr: Weydemeyer that he would see me to-morrow Morning. Notwithstanding which I sent him my note. Long walk after dinner— Mr: de Tracy and Mr de Castries spent an hour of the Evening with us.

8. VI. Good-Friday. Employed great part of the day in making the copy and translation of my official Note to Mr Weydemeyer. I called at half past eleven this morning to see him at the Hotel of the Department of foreign Affairs, being the time and place appointed by him. I found him with an excessively bad cough and apparently some fever. He had my Note in his hand, and was just reading it— I told him it would explain to him the subject upon which I had requested to see him. He assured me that he would immediately, transmit the contents of my Note to the Emperor, and was certain that His Majesty would receive with peculiar Satisfaction the testimonials of continued friendship, from the Government of the United States— He asked me whether I wished for an Audience, of the Empress-Mother, to take leave, or only to be presented to her for that purpose— I said that I wished in that respect precisely what was customary— He said that there was more Ceremony in an Audience; but as my absence was to be only temporary, and I expected to return it was merely a presentation that was customary— I told him that would be then what I should wish, and as I presumed there would be as usual a Court on Easter-Monday, which is next week, I had supposed it might suit the Empress’s convenience that I should take leave of her on that day, and had therefore sent him my Note, in Season to obtain Her Majesty’s orders before that time. He promised to take care of it, and to give me seasonable notice of the time she should appoint— I mentioned to him that Mr Harris was to be left here as Chargé d’Affaires. That I had written to him to give him notice of this arrangement; and
that his return might be expected very shortly. I referred him also to the part of my Note, disavowing the answer stated by Lord Castlereagh to have been given by the American Envoys, to the proposition of a Negotiation at London or Gothenburg made in Lord Cathcart’s Note to Count Nesselrode, dated 1. September 1813 at Töplitz.— He said he would not fail to make the Emperor acquainted with it.— From Mr Weydemeyer’s I went to Baron Blome’s, and found him at home. I had not seen him since last October, when he was recalled, but concluded not to leave this Country. He said he had been sick almost the whole winter; and always confined to the house— The Peace between Denmark and Russia was made, and Mr Lizakewitz had returned to Copenhagen— But he, Blome, had nothing yet from his Government— We had a conversation of an hour and a half upon the whole range of political subjects;—Norway, France, Sweden, the American and English War, the news from the Armies, and Count Romanzoff— Blome’s opinions with regard to Napoleon’s condition are nearly the same as my own. He considers him at the lowest extreme of desperation, and holds it impossible for him to save Paris from the allies. He is as might be expected very inveterate against Bernadotte, but represents his character and motives in his own peculiar point of view. Says he has done nothing for the allies— That his Swedes have scarcely burnt an ounce of gunpowder, that he hung back at Leipzig; that he ought to have been at Brienne; in which case the whole affair would have been finished then— That his real hatred and that of all the Swedes was against Russia, as I should see if I went into that Country. That it was astonishing how the allies were besotted in their admiration of Bernadotte, and the like— As to Norway, he said the Swedes would find it harder to take, and to keep that Country than they were aware— The people there would be, and must be, starved into submission; but Sweden would be forced to keep there a considerable number of troops, and to feed them too, which she could not easily do— The Norwegians had declared themselves independent; at peace with all the world, and determined only to defend themselves against any power that should attack them— They had sent deputies to England, but the English pleading their engagements with Sweden had refused to receive them— Bernadotte had made very light of the whole affair, but it would yet give him trouble. The Baron told me he had seen Count Romanzoff yesterday, and found him in very good Spirits— He mentioned to me the Counts present political situation, which I well knew before— He also told me that when he had intended to go away last Autumn he intended to have deposited with me the archives of his Legation, and had obtained the approbation of his Government for it— But they were now all sent away— I called on Mr Strong at the Hotel de l’Europe; and looked over his travelling Books and maps.— I went to Countess Colombi’s, and examined a travelling Carriage which she has for sale, a dormeuse—a very good Carriage but somewhat heavy. I Saw the Countess, and her Sister Clémentine; with the two Miss Betancourt’s— Mr Zea came in, while I was there. Mr Lewis wrote me a note, to say there was a report upon the Exchange, of an Armistice between the Allies and Napoleon.— He was here in the Evening and repeated the information.

9. VI. Mr Norman called upon me this Morning. The Coachmaker has sold his Carriage. He went with me, and looked at the one, at Countess Colombi’s; which he judged as I had done— I determined to enquire farther on Monday and Tuesday, and if I do not then find a Carriage to suit me better, to take this one.— We went to look at one advertised in the Papers, but it was not to be seen untill next week. Mr Norman went and saw another, likewise advertised; but found it not fit for travelling. He called on me a second time, and promised to be on the lookout for me on Monday and Tuesday. Mrs Adams visited Mrs Bailey and Mrs Krehmer, and invited them to dine with us next Thursday, when we are to have the Christening of Mr Smith’s child.— I walked after dinner. The Report of the Armistice, proves to be a lie— That of Blucher’s Victory, and the taking of Rheims is confirmed—

10. VI. Easter day— I received two Notices from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, that there would be a Te Deum to-morrow for a Victory of the Allies under the command of Field Marshal Blucher, and for the taking of Rheims par Assaut; and a notification from Mr Weydemeyer, that I am to be presented to the Empress Mother to take leave, at the Cercle Diplomatique— I read prayers for Easter-Sunday, and during the remainder of the day was employed chiefly in writing letters—to Mr Rodde at Reval—Count Engeström; and Mr Speyer. Walk before and after dinner. There are not so many of the Sheds for Shows on the Square this year as usual, and the numbers of People in the Streets were fewer than I have ever seen them here on this occasion.

11. VI. At 12 O’Clock I went with Mr Smith to the Winter Palace, and attended the Te Deum, for Marshal Blucher’s Victory, and the taking of Rheims, par Assaut; and the Cercle Diplomatique, afterwards held by the Empress Mother. It had been preceded by the Mass, which we did not attend. The foreign Ministers were there, excepting the Chevalier Bardaxi, and Captain Guedes. I gave Mr: Sterky the Agent Géneral from Sweden my letter to Count Engeström, enclosed in that to Mr Speyer; he promised to forward it by the earliest possible opportunity— I told him I should ask him for Passports which he promised to give me. When the Mass was finished the foreign Ministers were introduced into the Chapel for the Te Deum, in the performance of which there was a variation from the customary manner— The kneeling was omitted. They said it was always so at Easter-time. But last year there was a Te Deum at the Kazan, Easter-Tuesday, when they knelt as usual.— We withdrew from the Chapel just before the Te Deum closed, to be ready in the Salle du Trone for the Cercle— I was presented to take leave by Prince Tuffekin— The Empress asked me several questions about my journey, wished it might be pleasant, and hoped to see me soon again &c. I offered to take her Majesty’s Commands if she had any for that Country, which she received graciously and with thanks.— It was a kiss-hands Court, which Count Maistre forgot, and then was au desespoir at his inattention— We waited as usual some time after the Cercle to go to the Grand-Duchess Ann’s Apartments. Lord Walpole to repose himself literally lay down on the steps of the throne— There are no chairs in that Hall, I suppose because it is not of etiquette to be seated there. I was presented to the Grand-Duchess, to take leave, by her Ecuyer, Count Soltykoff— Her questions were much the same as those of the Empress-Mother. But she asked me whether I intended to go through Sweden or through Germany, at which Jouffroy the Prussian Chargé d’Affairs was much diverted. She told Jouffroy that he must feel very happy to be the Countryman of such a Hero as Marshal Blücher— She spoke to Lord Walpole too about the hero Wellington— Like other young Ladies she is a great admirer of Heroes— As there is no abundance of Neapolitan heroes she always speaks to the Duke de Serra-Capriola in Italian— In general there was not quite so much triumph and exultation at this Court, as there has been at the preceding Te Deum’s these 18 Months— Count Maistre whose son is Aide de Camp to General Wittgenstein, and was wounded with him at Bar sur Aube was much dejected— He said that we were singing a Te Deum for some Cannons but that the allies had suffered considerable defeats, and great losses— That we should see the Moniteur— That the resistance was greater than had been expected; that there were divisions among the allies &c— Yet they are advancing again on all quarters and are almost at the gates of Paris— The real truth is that the French are not in force to resist them. Princess Woldemar Galitzin was at the Te Deum, not knowing that her Grandson, young Count Strogonoff has been killed, though it has been known all over the city these ten days.— Count Maistre was informed only by accident of his son’s being wounded, and that it was but slightly— He mentioned it to the Empress who offered to transmit letters to or from him— Vous savez said she, que j’ai d’excellens Commissionaires a l’armée a présent— J’ai quatre fils a l’armée, and it gives me many a moment of heart-ache— As she went away I said to the Count, Bella matribus detestata— Aye, said he; but for her sons there is no great danger; though to be sure the Ball that killed Moreau, might have struck the Emperor— After we had been at the Grand-Duchess’s Court, we went to the Apartments of the Duke and Duchess of Wirtemberg, and were written down. The Duke, was present at the Te Deum— He commanded at the Siege of Dantzig.— From the Palace I went and paid visits by Cards to Countess Litta, Mr Gourieff, Prince Kurakin, Count Romanzoff, Mr Weydemeyer, the Duke de Serra-Capriola, Count Maistre, and Lord Walpole— It was near five O’Clock when we came home. After dinner I went with Charles to the Gachellies, and saw the Puppet-Show— Finished the Evening with writing.

12. V:30. I paid several visits this morning, previous to my departure— First to Mr Schubert, the Imperial Astronomer, to whom I returned the Celestial Charts by Bode, which he had lent me; and he returned me the volume on Comets, and that of Smith’s philosophical Essays, which I had lent him. He said he had read them both with great pleasure— That in Mr Oliver’s Essay upon Comets there was nothing new, as its principal idea that the Comets were retained in their orbits by the repulsion of the Solar atmosphere had been first advanced by Kepler, and was set forth in great detail by Pingré in a large work in two Volumes entitled Cometographie— I observed to him that Mr Oliver’s Essay must have been published before Pingre’s work— I asked him if the Planet Mercury could ever be seen by the naked eye— He said, not by him; nor by any ordinary eyes— That there was a young man, connected with the Academy of Sciences, who he did not doubt could at times see Mercury without a glass, for he could in a clear day see Venus at Noon— But for himself he could see nothing less than a
star of the 5th: magnitude with the naked eye— In Southern Climates, where the sky is clearer, more perhaps might be seen, but not here. He said that the light of Mercury was so brilliant, that it was necessary to use a coloured glass to view him distinctly.— From Mr Schubert’s I went to Mr Meyer’s, where I made some necessary arrangements, with respect to my family during my absence. I next called upon Mr Hynam, and returned him the Manuscript he lent me last Summer concerning the Russian weights and measures. He has two new pair of Scales, one of which he thinks still more perfect for small weights than his large one— But upon trial we found it less correct. He had also two antient Russian weights; but he knew not where made nor when— They were a pound and a quarter of a pound— They had the appearance of being made with care, and were marked in the 96th: parts of the Zolotnik—that is 9216 to the pound. It weighed 6326 grains Troy weight English—that is 6 3/4 grains more than the standard weight now used at the fortress for weighing silver and gold—which yields another proof how excessively careless they are here upon this Article— The quarter of a pound corresponded very exactly with the pound, and proved that they were taken from a standard heavier than that now used— Mr Hynam shewed me again all his apparatus for making Arsheens— Of which he told me he had been engaged to make 500000. that the number wanted, was about four millions, but the war had put a stop to the work— His machinery is all extremely ingenious, and of his own invention— After returning home I went with Charles to the Gachellies, two of which we saw—the Rope-dancers, Tumblers and feats of horsemanship; and the Punch puppet-show, with the leger-de-main tricks. About 4 we came home, and I went to look at some travelling Carriages for sale. Found one to suit me— Mr Norman sent me word that he had been seeking all over the City, yesterday and this day; with no better success— I concluded to take Countess Colombi’s Dormeuse— She was here this morning to visit Mrs Adams, who in return, spent the Evening there. I met after dinner and walked with Mr de Tracy, who is not quite so sangwine as he was, but still credits too lightly the flattering tale of Hope. We met and spoke to Mr Montreal, who is yet unwell with his cough. After I returned home I had an Evening visit from Count Maistre.— George’s Birth-day— Charles measures 3 f 8 l/4 i.

13. VI. I took Charles this morning to school, and informed Mr Fishwick that as I expected to leave my family here, I should keep him another Quarter at School. I then called upon Mr Norman at his lodgings; he told me that he had searched all over the City for Carriages, and found none so good or at so reasonable a price as that of Madame Colombi. He determined to go with me, without waiting any longer for the English mails, if I concluded to go by the way of Memel. I called at Mr Meyer’s to leave a letter, and thence walked home— The Carriage was sent home from Countess Colombi’s— After dinner, I rode out with Mrs Adams and then walked alone— Charles came home again from school and went to a party at Mr Cayley’s.

14. VI:15. Mr Strong called upon me this morning, and brought with him a minute of the road from Memel to this place as he travelled it— I was engaged great part of the day in writing to the Secretary of State. Mr: and Mrs Bayley, Mr: and Mrs Krehmer, Mr and Mrs Gisborne, Mrs Fisher, Dr: Beresford, Mr Brüxner, Messrs: Lewis, Slade, Strong, Norman, Hurd and Gould, dined with us;—Mr Meyer sent an excuse, and Dr: Galloway without sending an excuse did not come. Just before dinner we had the christening of Mr Smith’s child: for whom Mrs Adams and Mrs Gisborne stood as God-mothers, and myself as God-father. She was Christened by Dr Beresford, by the name of Caroline-Amelia. Dr: Beresford told me that there was an English Church at Gothenburg, for which he intended to offer himself as a Candidate— He also told me that he was writing the lives of the German Poets; with translated specimens of their works— His book would be biographical and critical in humble imitation of Dr: Johnson, but without Johnson’s moroseness— He also acknowledged to me that he did not believe the Athanasian Creed; had never read it since he was in England, and never would read it again.— I received this morning a note from Mr Hynam concerning the old Russian weights I had seen at his house. He says he is informed by Mr Zachareff, in the Academy (of Sciences) that they were brought by Peter the Great, from Holland; and were made by him the Original Standard— But how the Standard came to be changed, and how that now used, came to be 6 3/4 Grains Troy weight lighter, he does not ascertain. I have not time to pursue these enquires any farther.

15. V.45. I went this morning to the shops in search of various objects, but without success. Called to visit the Father General of the Jesuits, but he was not at home— During the whole of Passion and Easter-weeks, almost all the shops in this City are shut up, and nothing is to be done— This multiplicity of festivals, and consequent idleness is suitable to a People of Slaves, and no other— I took a second walk, after dinner.— Charles returned to School this morning, having come home to the Christening. I am making some preparations for my departure.

16. VI. After Charles returned from School, I went with him and saw the two remaining Shows at the Gachellies— They were the Chinese Shadows, and the Rope-dancers and Tumblers with the three-handed man. I afterwards walked on the Admiralty Boulevard, and met Mr Zea and Don Francisco Colombi, who told me they had received the official news that Lord Wellington had had completely beaten Soult, and was pursuing him towards Toulouse, and that a Spanish division had taken Bordeaux— They said the Allies had concentrated themselves into one army, and were manoeuvreing— On the 25th. of March they were at Vitry— I rode with Mrs: Adams after dinner, in the procession round the Squares, and afterwards walked, again— Received a letter from Mr Harris dated 14. March at Amsterdam.

17. V.45. This is regularly the last of the Easter Holidays, but this year they are to be continued two or three days longer, by order of the Empress Mother, in rejoycing for new and great victories obtained by the allies over Napoleon, of which the news was brought by a Courier this day. The weather was fine and warm, and the crowds of people on the walks, and in the Squares great.— I read prayers for the Sunday after Easter, and some of Jortin’s Remarks on Ecclesiastical History.— Mrs: Adams, Mr Smith, Charles and I dined at Mr Krehmer’s— Mr & Mrs Brown, Miss Cazalet, Mr Norman, Mr Lewis, Messrs: Cavenagh and Regale were there— We also spent the Evening there at Cards, and it was past one in the Morning when we came home. Mr Rodde of Reval had called upon me this morning, and told me that there would certainly be good opportunities of going by Water from Reval to Stockholm, as soon as the Navigation is open; which must be in a very few days— He said the Roads were so bad that I should lose no time by waiting a few days longer before my departure— He expects to go himself about the beginning of the next week— I concluded to go that way and about the same time— I mentioned to Mr Norman my regret that we shall not be able to go on together.— I finished this day the first part of my Chronological Essay, for my Children.

18. VI:30. There was a Te Deum at the Cazan Church for the late victories of the allies, but having taken leave at Court I received no notice to attend it. I had a morning visit from Baron Blome, who mentioned to me the particulars of the last actions, in which Rapatel was killed with a bayonet in sight of the Emperor— Napoleon is reduced to the last extremity, and his fate cannot be much longer delayed. In the Evening the whole City was illuminated. I dined with Mrs Adams and Mr Smith at the English Consul Mr Bayley’s. Mr and Mrs Labensky, an old Lady, named Miss Chamberlain, a Sir James Riddle and Mr James, English Gentleman, and Mr Strong & Mr Lewis formed the Company— We came home between nine and ten in the Evening.— The river broke up about 5 O’Clock this Morning— I was going with Charles to School, but we found the Bridge carried away, and could not cross the river. We walked home.

19. V.45. i made some of the preparations for my departure, but as always happens I apply too much of my time to objects not adapted to the occasion— Walked before and after dinner— Met Mr Lewis and walked with him— He spent the Evening with us— I also met Messieurs de Tracy and de Castres. Read some pages in Jortin’s remarks on Ecclesiastical History.

20. VI. i went with Charles this morning to school. Cross’d the river in boats— Returning home I called upon Mr Rodde, at Rex’s. He told me he had received letters from Revel, yesterday dated the 1/13 that the harbour was not then open, and they expected it would not be in less than three weeks from that time— But the very warm weather of last week and at present must break up the ice sooner than they had expected— Mr Rodde mentioned that he had a small Schooner of about 20 Lasts loading directly for Gothenburg, a very good vessel, and fast Sailor, in which if it should suit me I might take my passage. On arriving at Reval, I shall determine which way to proceed.— About 2 O’Clock this afternoon one of the Palace Courier’s came in great haste to congratulate me on the taking of Paris. An Estafette had just arrived to the Empress Mother with the news. The Reports in Circulation afterwards through the day were various— The Estafette came from the Governor of Königsberg— The news to him was from the military Government at Berlin; and to them from Field-Marshal Blücher who took the City on the 29th: of March— I had morning visits from Mr Hurd and Mr Gould; and from Mr Montreal.— Walked after dinner with Mrs: Adams.

21. VI. i continue the preparations for my departure. Many of them concern minute objects, and after all I shall go much unprepared. Mr: Peyron called upon me with a small packet for Stockholm. I dined with Mr Smith at Mr Raimberts—Messrs: de Tracy, Castries, and Chabannes were there— The news of the taking of Paris, with all the details, was said to be confirmed by the Berlin Gazettes, this day arrived— The letters and Papers had not generally been delivered; but some persons had already received theirs, and from them the news came— Tracy was in extreme anxiety and agitation. Mr Raimbert deeply dejected— Montréal not much less distressed,
but struggling more to preserve the appearance of tranquillity. The Consolat’s said little, but felt like the rest of the family— Castries and Chabannes were calm and cool. Their fathers are emigrants of the Bourbon party, and they risk little, whatever the Event may be. Their real feeling and interest is probably with the allies. After dinner the Abbé de Fermont came in— Tracy was still snatching at straws to build doubts upon; but no other person had any— I walked about an hour after dinner— Mrs Adams, with Charles spent the Evening at Mrs Krehmer’s where there was a party of children.

22. V.15. Walked with Charles this morning to school, and crossed the river with some difficulty; it blew a gale of wind, and the current sat so strongly down the river that we landed half a quarter of a Mile below the proper place. I recrossed the river opposite the Academy of Arts; and in a larger Boat.— Wrote Notes to Mr Weydemeyer requesting Passports for myself and for Mr Strong, and I sent a Note to Count Romanzoff requesting to see him before my departure— I was much employed the whole day, but walked again after dinner— Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us, untill near Midnight.

24. VI.45. I read prayers for the second Sunday after Easter, and was engaged almost all the remainder of the day in writing. Dr: Beresford dined with us, and mentioned again his intention of offering himself as a Candidate for the English Church at Gothenburg. He shewed me his letter to the Duke of Portland in 1800. to Sir James Crawford the English Minister at Hamburg in 1801. and to the Editor of the Morning Chronicle in 1795. justifying himself against the suspicion of having been concerned with Stone, who was tried for Treason— The poor Doctor wishes me to use my influence in his favour at Gothenburg; and I promised him faithfully that if I could serve him I would— But I candidly told him that I was afraid any sollicitation of mine in his favour, would do him more harm than good.— The Courier with the taking of Paris is not yet arrived, but was this day announced by a feld-jäger.

25. V.45. As I was going this morning with Charles to school, we heard on the Quay the Report of 50 Cannon from the fortress, announcing the arrival of General Golenischtcheff-Kutuzoff, the official Courier with the news of the taking of Paris by the Allies, on the 31st: of March. After leaving Charles at Mr Fishwick’s I called at Mr Norman’s lodgings, but he was not at home— I then called at Mr Sterky’s, but he had not the Passport and letters ready for me— He promised to bring them to me, which he afterwards did— Baron Klinkowström and he met at my house— The Baron came to ask me to take a packet for his Lady which I promised. Mr Norman and Mr Montréal likewise paid me Morning visits— I wrote to the Secretary of State, and took a second walk after dinner— The preparations for the illumination are great at a few particular houses; but not yet very general.

26. V:30. Mr: Norman called upon me this Morning, and brought me two letters to his friends at Gothenburg and at London. I gave him the Courier’s Passport that I had procured for him Yesterday— Mr Montreal was also here in the Morning, and Baron Blome and Mr Strong in the Evening. The Baron gave me a letter for Copenhagen— I gave Mr Strong his Passport, and despatches; with several Packets for Mr Bayard, sent me by Mr Weydemeyer— Countess Colombi, and her Sister Miss Clementine Bode spent the Evening here with the Ladies— I went this morning to the Shops, and purchased some of the Articles necessary for my Journey. Called on the Father General Brzozowsky, and took leave of him. The day was busily employed, but I wrote to my Mother.

27. V.15. I was employed the whole day in packing up and preparing for my departure. About an hour before dinner I walked out to some shops to purchase some necessary Articles for the Journey. Mr Smith attended the Te Deum for Paris— I did not attend, it being the rule of etiquette not to appear in presence of the Empress after having taken leave— The notice for the last preceding Te Deum was not even sent me. I supposed this one was sent for Mr Smith— I was likewise so busy with my preparations, that I could not conveniently spare the time— I went out however with Mrs: Adams and Charles in the Evening to see the illuminations which were universal, and some of them splendid— The most brilliant of all were those at the fortress. It was very cold, and the wind blew so strong that all the designs of illumination were baffled in the Execution— For before any one of them was completely lighted, half of the lamps were blown up— In many places where expensive preparations had been made they totally failed— At others the Lamplighters were constantly employed in relighting the extinguished lamps but the wind blew out faster than they could light— There were some transparencies, but none remarkable for ingenuity. The letter A. was repeated in thousands of Forms, and there were a few Russian, Latin and French mottoes. The crowd of Carriages, and of People walking in the Streets was very great— It was near one in the morning when we returned home—

28. VI. I had finally fixed upon this day for my departure on the Journey to Gothenburg; and was employed from the time of my rising, untill half past One P.M. in finishing my preparations. I had visits during the morning from Mr Hurd, Mr Norman, and Mr Montreal, the last of whom informed me that a Courier had this morning arrived from the Emperor, with the news that Napoleon Bonaparte, on having the Decree of the French Senate notified to him declaring that he was cashiered, had immediately abdicated the throne, and thus that the War is at an end. With this prospect of a general Peace in Europe, I commenced my Journey, to contribute if possible to the restoration of Peace to my own Country— The weight of the trust committed though but in part to me; the difficulties to all human appearance insuperable, which forbid the hope of success; the universal gloom of the prospect before me, would depress a mind of more sangwine complexion than mine— On the Providence of God alone is my reliance— The prayer for light, and vigilence, and presence of mind and fortitude, and resignation, in fine for strength proportioned to my trial is incessant upon my heart— The welfare of my family and Country, with the interests of Humanity, are staked upon the Event— To Heaven alone it must be committed— That my duty may be performed in sincerity, with fervent zeal, and unsullied integrity is my heart’s desire and prayer to God.— And let his will be done!

At half past One O’Clock afternoon I left my house, after taking leave of Mr and Mrs Smith. My dear wife and Charles came with me to Strelna, the first Stage, where we dined together at the Post-house opposite the Grand-Duke Constantine’s Summer-Palace. At half past four I embraced them, and committed them to the Protection of a kind and gracious Providence, and proceeded on my Journey, with my Servant Axel Gabriel Gåhlroos a native of Åbo in Finland, whom I have engaged to go with me.

This table contains the itinerary of my journey from St: Petersburg to Reval— Upon my application to Mr Weydemeyer, he sent me a Passport for my self and my Servant; with a sealed letter to General Wiasmitinoff the Military Governor of the City, which I sent yesterday to him, on which he furnished me the Padorojna or Order for Post-horses— The order was for four Courier horses, and was to be exhibited to the Post-Master at every Station. It mentioned that the road was from St: Petersburg to Reval—that it was 341 Versts, the horses to be paid for at the rate fixed by the Ukazes, and that 27 Rubles 28 Copeeks, that is 8 Copeeks per Verst was paid for this Padorojna.— For the horses the first Stage, to Strelna the charge was seven Copeeks for each horse per Verst, and the rest of the Road 5 Copeeks per Verst and horse— At each stage I paid 50 Copeeks to the Postilion, and 25 Copeeks to the Starost, or Peasant who furnished the horses.— They were all satisfied with this, and never asked for more— I have marked down in the table the legal payments at each Stage, including the 75 Copeeks to the Postilion and Starost— The first Stage also includes the 28 Rubles for the Padorojna, the Governor’s Clerk who made it out having kept the odd Copeeks for himself. My actual payments were in some instances more than I have here set down, but the difference was a mere trifle. I have also marked the time of my arrival at each Stage, and of my departure from it; which will shew the average rate of travelling, and the time of detention at each Post-house for the horses. It was never less than half an hour, and seldom much more, excepting
when I stopp’d to take some refreshment, or to have the wheels of the Carriage greased.— I found the roads this Evening excessively rough— The Snow was gone almost universally— The frost had come out of the ground making the roads deep and they were now frozen hard again— The weather was cold, but the Night clear; and with a Moon nearly at the full.— I concluded therefore to travel the whole Night. At Koskova, I remarked the conjunction of the Moon and Jupiter.

29. At the two Stages from Koskova to Opolié, which I travelled between 1 and 5 O’Clock this morning there was still some depth of Snow, and the roads were worse than upon any other part of the road. I breakfasted at Jamburg, and crossed the river Luga there, about 9. The road to Narva from the river is in a straight line, and fine as a turnpike. The Post house at Narva is without the City which I therefore did not enter. Crossed the river Narova just below it— This Circumstance of the Post house’s being without the City I suppose is the Cause that two Versts more are charged for on the Stage which enters the City, from either side. But when the traveller does not enter the City, as was my case, they do not charge the additional Versts for both Stages. I crossed the river, just at Noon, under the salutation of 30 or 40 Guns, which on enquiry, I found were fired in rejoycing for the taking of Paris— At the Post-Office at Chudleigh the name was painted upon the door of the house. The place is grossly misspelt on the Post-map, and in the Books. I asked the Post-master how it came by its English name— He said that the Estate upon which it was built, had been purchased by the Duchess of Kingston, and that she had long resided at the Chateau, in view of the place where we stood, and which he pointed out to me— That the name of the place had been Fokenoff, which sounded hässlich in English; for which reason the Duchess had changed it for her own maiden-name— I met here a traveller; almost the only one I had seen upon the road; with the exception of two Couriers; one last Night, and one this morning; and both beyond Narva towards St: Petersburg— This traveller asked me if there was any late news from the Armies at St: Petersburg— I told him of the taking of Paris— He said he knew that; but shook his head, and said he feared the worst danger was yet to come.— I had neither time nor inclination to enquire into the motives of his fears, and wished him a pleasant Journey— The same Post-master at Chudleigh gave me, and charged me for six horses instead of four, which from St: Petersburg to that place had been sufficient for me. Several of the preceding Starosts had indeed spoken of six horses, but Mrs Colombi had told me her husband never had travelled in it with more than four, and I knew not that more than four were required by the ordinances. This Post-Master had the printed Ordinances suspended at the Wall of the room where I waited for the change of the horses— They were dated in 1801. 1808 and 1812. the last at Willna— It regulates the price to be paid for the horses; at 5 Copeeks for each horse per Versts—in this and the neighbouring Governments. It had been previously only 3 Copeeks per Verst; and before the paper Currency only two. The Ordinance of 1808 prescribed the number of horses to be taken and charged for every sort of Carriage from two horses to ten— The number for each kind of vehicle is increased by one or two, at the two Seasons of the Year when the roads are broken up— Thus the two seated Coach; with trunks, and two or three Persons, takes four horses from 15 December to 15 March, and from 15 May to 15 September— During the rest of the year the same Carriage and burden must take six horses. My Carriage is of this description, and in the heavy parts of the road really needed the six horses— The breed of these horses is peculiar to the Country. They are very small; very wretched in appearance, and very weak; which last quality must be owing to their bad keeping— For they are hardy—they endure the extremities of the Cold as if it was their natural temperature, and they are fleet— The price charged for horses is lower than in any other Country in Europe. And they exact much more from travellers who have not the Padorojna for Courier horses. It has not even been increased in proportion to the depretiation of the Paper; for two Copeeks in silver are equal to eight of Copper or Paper.— We arrived at Wargel between 10 and 11 in the Evening.— The weather had changed and it began to Snow. I determined therefore to stop for the Night, and had my bed made in a room which they allowed me at the Post-house.

30. IV. They gave me a Breakfast of very good Coffee, and rye-bread— The Post-master attempted to charge me nearly double the fixed price for his horses, but desisted upon my asking him for an explanation. At six, I entered the Carriage— There had fallen so much Snow in the Night that the ground was entirely covered— It continued to Snow at intervals all the first part of the day. In the afternoon it cleared away, but still continued very cold. In the course of the day I read the pamphlet upon expatriation, sent me by Mr Monroe the Secretary of State. Mr Strong told me it was written by Mr George Hay who married Mr Monroe’s daughter. The author appears to me to have proved beyond all possibility of reply the falsehood, absurdity and tyranny of the doctrine of perpetual allegiance— But I cannot altogether reconcile my self to his doctrine of the unqualified right of expatriation.
I consider the social compact as bilateral— Allegiance and Protection as reciprocal and corresponding obligations of the Subject and Sovereign— But it is a compact, and I cannot think it dissoluble at the mere pleasure of either party.— I also began this day to read Clark’s naval History of the United States.— Stopp’d about an hour and dined at Loop. I had proceeded about four Versts from Kahal, the last Stage but one before Reval, when between 8 and 9 in the Evening my Servant discovered that the Crane Neck of the Carriage was broken entirely off. We proceeded with much difficulty about three Versts further, to the next Village, where with the Assistance of several peasants the broken parts of the Carriage were lashed together so that we were enabled between Midnight, and one in the morning to reach the Post-Station at Jegelicht— On descending from the Carriage we found that the first accident had occasioned a second and more serious one. My Servants Portmanteau, containing all his Clothes and all the money he had was lashed on in front of the Carriage, and under his own Seat— After the Carriage was broken it became necessary to remove it, and he lashed it on the trunk behind. When we arrived at the Station it was gone— Whether the ropes which had held it were cut away, or had been worn off by the friction, was not perfectly clear— We had seen no person upon the road; and Axel thought he had seen his Portmanteau still on the Trunk about 8 Versts behind the Post-house— I stopp’d here untill the morning, to give him time to go back, and see if he could find it on the road. The Mail for St: Petersburg from Reval was going through, about two hours after, and I wrote by it a few lines to my wife— I then had my Mattrass thrown upon a Sopha, and laid down, without being able to sleep from two untill about six in the Morning.

Day. Untill the last three days, the distribution of my time has been like that of the preceding Months; but my principal occupation has been to prepare for the Journey which I have now commenced. At present there can of course be no regularity in my mode of life. The Scene changes from day to day, and from hour to hour. I have become once more a wayfaring man; and am separated from every part of my family— Before the close of the next Month I hope to be again stationary; at least enough so to resume an orderly disposal of my Time.
